The patient is a 69-year-old man with a history of hypertension, prostate cancer, and left nephrostomy for retroperitoneal fibrosis. He was admitted to the floor for hematuria, nausea, vomiting, and left flank pain. The patient's condition has deteriorated, presenting with increasing right flank pain, nausea, vomiting, chills, and decreased urine output from the left nephrostomy. In the emergency department, his vital signs were unstable, with blood pressure readings ranging from 98/60 to 125/70 mmHg. The patient has a high white blood cell count and band percentage, indicating a possible infection. A CT abdomen showed right hydro, and he received morphine, albuterol, and ciprofloxacin. The patient's blood pressure remained low but improved after the placement of a right internal jugular (IJ) line.

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus, asthma, left knee cyst, chronic back pain, and no known drug allergies. His medications at home include prilosec, tamsulosin, finasteride, simvastatin, omeprazole, SSI, hep s/q, and docusate. The patient denies tobacco, drug, or alcohol use.

Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the current symptoms. Flow sheet data shows vital signs within normal ranges, with a heart rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/68 to 125/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 16 mmHg, total fluid input of 1,863 mL, and output of 530 mL, primarily from the left nephrostomy. The patient is receiving respiratory support with a nasal cannula and has clear breath sounds with occasional wheezes.

Physical examination reveals no acute distress, with normal eye and head/neck findings. Cardiovascular examination shows normal heart sounds, and peripheral pulses are not assessed. Respiratory examination notes clear breath sounds with occasional wheezes. Abdominal examination is soft, non-tender, with bowel sounds present and mild right costovertebral angle tenderness. Extremities are absent on the right side and unobtainable on the left side. Neurologic examination shows an attentive patient who follows simple commands but has not been assessed further.

Lab results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 11.7 K/uL, elevated creatinine at 3.5 mg/dL, low hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, elevated potassium at 5.5 mg/dL, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. Other labs are within normal ranges.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient is diagnosed with septicemia from obstructive pyelonephritis with gram-negative bacilli bacteremia. He is currently being treated with ciprofloxacin and may require a percutaneous nephrostomy. The patient also has acute renal failure, likely secondary to combination of hydronephrosis and hypovolemia from sepsis. The cause of elevated bilirubin is unclear, and the patient will be monitored. Anemia will be evaluated due to mild elevated bilirubin. The cause of retroperitoneal fibrosis remains unclear. The patient is receiving ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
